Eastern Speckled Shield Lichen

Punctelia bolliana

Punctelia bolliana is a pale gray-green foliose lichen recognized by its large, rounded lobes, distinct white pseudocyphellae, and dark brown to black underside with simple rhizines. It is one of the most common Punctelia species on hardwood bark across the central and eastern United States and is frequently mistaken for Flavoparmelia caperata or Physcia species until the underside and pseudocyphellae are examined closely.

Eastern Speckled Shield — Winter Rosette
A broad, pale gray foliose colony with scattered white pseudocyphellae and darkened undersides visible at curled lobe margins.
Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 200 • Aperture f/13 • Shutter 3.2 s
E21A8093–8107 • Size: 3854×5781

This colony shows several diagnostic features of P. bolliana:

  • white pseudocyphellae scattered across the thallus surface
  • large lobes with smooth, rounded edges
  • dark interior folds at the lobe base (confirming a brown-to-black underside)
  • a subtly mottled gray-green pigmentation rather than the mint-green of Flavoparmelia.

Description

Punctelia bolliana forms loosely attached foliose rosettes ranging from a few centimeters to large, multi-rosette mats. The upper surface is smooth to slightly wrinkled, typically pale gray-green, and faintly mottled.
Its most characteristic trait is the presence of pseudocyphellae—tiny white pores where the cortex is broken, dotting the thallus surface.

The lower surface is dark brown to nearly black, with simple rhizines concentrated toward the center and thinning at the margins.

This combination—gray thallus, white pseudocyphellae, black underside—is the core field diagnosis for the species.

Identification

Scaled Lobe Study — Pseudocyphellae & Structure
Millimeter scale confirming broad lobe width and scattered white pseudocyphellae.
Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 200 • Aperture f/13 • Shutter 1 s
E21A8142 • Size: 5892×3928

Key features of Punctelia bolliana

  • Thallus: Pale gray-green; mottled, often pruinose
  • Lobes: Large (3–8 mm wide), rounded, overlapping
  • Pseudocyphellae: Small, white, abundant—the most reliable field mark
  • Underside: Dark brown to black with simple rhizines
  • Apothecia: Rare, brown with entire margins
  • Chemistry: Usually K+ yellow → red (in medulla), C–, P–

Distinguishing from similar species

  • vs. Flavoparmelia caperata (Common Greenshield)
    • F. caperata is yellow-green, never gray
    • underside paler
    • pseudocyphellae appear as pale cracks, not white dots
    • lobes have a different wrinkled texture
  • vs. Punctelia rudecta
    • rudecta has larger, more ragged pseudocyphellae and a rougher overall texture
    • bolliana has clean, round, evenly scattered white pores
  • vs. Physcia millegrana / stellaris
    • those species have tiny lobes (<1.5 mm), heavy soredia, and pale undersides
    • P. bolliana has much larger lobes and a dark underside

Fine Lobe Portrait

Speckled Shield Lobe Portrait
A close view revealing the smooth foliose texture, scattered pseudocyphellae, and gently uplifted margins of *P. bolliana*.
Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 200 • Aperture f/13 • Shutter 1 s
E21A8143 • Size: 5892×3928

This portrait highlights the subtle, diagnostic mix of traits: the pale gray-green color, the rounded lobes, and the numerous white pseudocyphellae that distinguish this species at a glance in macro view.

Habitat

In Minnesota, Punctelia bolliana is commonly found on:

  • elm, oak, ash, and maple bark
  • open to lightly shaded exposures
  • mature bark surfaces with stable moisture cycles

It tolerates more urban and nitrogen-enriched environments compared to more sensitive foliose lichens like Flavoparmelia.
